content.question: Suppose we wish to represent the electric potential around <math alttext="Q sub 1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> by drawing isolines. What is the relationship of the isolines of electric potential to the net electric field vectors in the region around <math alttext="Q sub 1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The isolines are always directed along the electric field vectors.
The isolines are always opposite the electric field vectors.
The isolines are always perpendicular to the electric field vectors.
The isolines are perpendicular to the electric field vectors when the field is uniform, but they can be at any angle to the vectors when the field is nonuniform.

content.answer: The isolines are always perpendicular to the electric field vectors.
